introPages.title: The function of conjunctions and linkers
introPages.body:
Conjunctions and linkers connect ideas and show the logical relationship between them. They tell the reader how one idea relates to another – whether we are adding, contrasting, explaining cause and effect, or showing time order.

Conjunctions typically join clauses within a sentence (and, but, because, when). Linkers (or discourse markers) often connect sentences or start a new sentence (however, therefore, meanwhile). Both serve the same purpose: they make the structure of your argument or narrative clear.

In Part 2, the gap often needs a conjunction or linker that expresses one of four essential logical relations.

introPages.title: Addition
introPages.body:
Addition links ideas that go together or add to each other. We add information, give more of the same, or build a list.

Common words: and, also, too, as well as, in addition, moreover, furthermore, besides.

Examples: She speaks English and French. / He is talented. Furthermore, he works hard. / In addition to the cost, there is the time factor.

introPages.title: Contrast and comparison
introPages.body:
Contrast shows that ideas differ, oppose each other, or present an unexpected twist. Comparison sets two things side by side.

Common words: but, however, although, though, whereas, while, on the other hand, nevertheless, despite, in spite of.

Examples: He tried hard, but he failed. / The weather was bad. However, we went out. / Whereas John prefers tea, Mary likes coffee. / Although he was tired, he continued.

introPages.title: Cause and effect
introPages.body:
Cause explains why something happens. Effect shows the result or consequence.

Cause: because, since, as, due to, because of, owing to

Effect: so, therefore, thus, as a result, consequently

Examples: We stayed home because it was raining. / It was raining; therefore, we stayed home. / Due to the bad weather, we cancelled.

introPages.title: Time sequence
introPages.body:
Time sequence shows the order of events – when something happens in relation to something else, or the steps in a process.

Common words: when, while, before, after, as, since, until, first, then, finally, meanwhile, subsequently.

Examples: When the bell rang, everyone left. / First, we prepare the mixture. Then, we add the flour. Finally, we bake it. / She made tea while he read the paper. / Nothing happened until she arrived.

mcQuiz.question: Which logical relation does furthermore express?
mcQuiz.explanation: Furthermore adds information – it expresses addition.

mcQuiz.question: Which logical relation does whereas express?
mcQuiz.explanation: Whereas sets two things side by side for contrast or comparison.

mcQuiz.question: Which logical relation does therefore express?
mcQuiz.explanation: Therefore introduces a result or effect.

mcQuiz.question: In She was cooking. Meanwhile, he set the table, what logical relation does meanwhile express?
mcQuiz.explanation: In this example, meanwhile shows two things happening at the same time – time sequence.

mcQuiz.question: In He tried hard. ___, he failed, which fits?
mcQuiz.explanation: The second clause contrasts with the first – use however (followed by a comma when it starts a sentence).

mcQuiz.question: In It was raining. ___ we stayed home, which fits?
mcQuiz.explanation: The second clause is the result of the first – use therefore.

mcQuiz.question: Which linker adds more information in formal writing?
mcQuiz.explanation: Moreover adds or strengthens a point – it expresses addition.

shortQuestions.question: Because of it was raining, we stayed home.
accepted: because it was raining, we stayed home
we stayed home because it was raining
shortQuestions.explanation: Use because + clause. Use because of + noun (e.g. because of the rain).

shortQuestions.question: Despite he tried hard, he failed.
accepted: although he tried hard, he failed
in spite of his efforts, he failed
shortQuestions.explanation: Despite takes a noun or -ing. Use although + clause, or despite trying / in spite of his efforts.

shortQuestions.question: I came here so that to learn English.
accepted: so that i could learn english
i came here in order to learn english
i came here to learn english
i came here so that i could learn english
shortQuestions.explanation: So that + clause. In order to / to + infinitive. Never 'so that to'.

shortQuestions.question: Despite of the rain, we went out.
accepted: despite the rain, we went out
in spite of the rain, we went out
shortQuestions.explanation: Despite is never followed by 'of'. Use despite or in spite of.

shortQuestions.question: Although he was tired, but he continued.
accepted: although he was tired, he continued
he was tired, but he continued
shortQuestions.explanation: Don't use but with although. Use one or the other.

shortQuestions.question: Due to the weather was bad, we cancelled.
accepted: due to the bad weather, we cancelled
because the weather was bad, we cancelled
shortQuestions.explanation: Due to + noun phrase. Use because + clause for a full clause.

shortQuestions.question: I suggest you to go early.
shortQuestions.explanation: Suggest + (that) + clause with base form, or suggest + -ing. Never 'suggest someone to do'.

optionalQuestionsBank.question: Name three linkers for addition and use each in a short example.
optionalQuestionsBank.suggested: e.g. Furthermore – He is talented. Furthermore, he works hard. / Moreover – The plan is risky. Moreover, it is expensive. / In addition – In addition to cost, there is the time factor.

optionalQuestionsBank.question: What is the difference between although and however in terms of position?
optionalQuestionsBank.suggested: Although typically starts a clause (Although he was tired, he continued). However typically starts a new sentence or comes after a semicolon (He was tired. However, he continued).

optionalQuestionsBank.question: Give two linkers for cause and two for effect.
optionalQuestionsBank.suggested: Cause: because, since, due to, owing to. Effect: therefore, so, thus, as a result, consequently.

optionalQuestionsBank.question: When might you use while vs when for time?
optionalQuestionsBank.suggested: While often suggests two things happening at the same time (She cooked while he read). When often suggests one event triggering another (When the bell rang, everyone left). Both can express time sequence.

optionalQuestionsBank.question: Explain the four main logical relations between ideas.
optionalQuestionsBank.suggested: Addition (and, furthermore, moreover); Contrast/comparison (but, however, although, whereas); Cause/effect (because, therefore, so, due to); Time sequence (when, while, before, after, first, then, finally, meanwhile).
